<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```java
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "A|87657|587688|832134|4";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```

<<<explanation>>>: The issue with the original code is that it is not properly handling the case where the second column contains only a single digit. To fix this, you can modify the `altStringTokenizer` method to check if the second token is a single digit before parsing it as an integer. If it is a single digit, then it should be treated as a string. Here's the modified code:
```java
static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        if (two.equals("")) {
            continue; // skip empty second column
        } else if (two.matches("\\d+")) {
            // parse as integer if it's a single digit
            int val = Integer.parseInt(two);
            output.put(type + ":" + one, val);
        } else {
            // parse as string if it's not a single digit
            output.put(type + ":" + one, two);
        }
    }
}
```
